title: Public Linked Open Data - the Publications Office's Contribution to the Semantic Web

author: Peter Schmitz, Publications Office of the European Union

segmentation: Good morning everybody.
As already said, my name is Peter Schmitz from the publications office of EU and we are now moving to the other side to the application of the things to build up systems which provides.
Multilingual open data for we use for the web.
So we're setting up currently a large repository and I will tell you a bit where we are.
I had the possibility two years ago.

To describe a bit our vision, Luckily we have advanced on this way and I will present you where we are an eventually to show you what we are providing an if it could be of use to be reused in one or another of your projects.
Just search.
But first of all, the short reminder, what is the publications office of CU at?
It's a publisher of the EU institutions and in general we have two kinds of publication.
We have the so called mandatory publications.
Which have to be published based on the Treaties and other agreements that is in particular legislation.
But we have also so-called non mandatory publication, which is everything over Books, E books posters reflect.

We also provide the services which are traditionally around this publication job, so allocation of international, standard numbers, cataloging indexing, distribution, promotion, sales, storage and archiving and archiving means also long-term digital preservation.
Last not least, we are in the middle of a big change initiative, so this repository is really to help us on the way from paper to electronic.
We are clearly shifting from paper to electronic and from a publisher to information provider.
And also in this context to a provider of multilingual linked open data.

This shift from paper to electronics that will be come really visible, I think during this year because there's a new regulation on the way to make the electronic version of the Official Journal legally binding.
So I think in the middle of the year we will be there that the electronic version of the OG.
Is legal binding?
Multilingualism for us.
It's core business simply because we have a daily, simultaneous and partially synoptic publication in up to 23 languages.
So every day there are several, oh geez, which are published normally in 22, sometimes in 23 languages and in summer we will have a new language creation.
Who will join the Union normally at the 1st of July?
What does it means here?

We are talking of considerable volumes, so just to give an example, just before Christmas we had an OG which was a international agreement between EU and South America which had two 2600 pages for each language.
So you can multiply this and that was one now.
And we have several pair days.
Not so big, but it's a considerable amount of data.
The other aspect for multilingualism is by definition, because we have to support all Member States equally.
We have by default multilingual public websites.
The most important websites are your legs, which is access to to the European law.
That which is for the public procurement, we have Cordis which certainly is one another from you knows very well for the research community.
And we have your book shop for the general publications.
What I want to do now is to to pick up for systems which we are currently developing setting up.
Which can contribute to the multilingual semantic web.
That means first of all the common repository for content and metadata, which is called seller.
Zillow data portal.
The open data hub of the European Union.
You revoke our multilingual thesaurus and our meta data registry.
Let's start with a common repository is a seller.
That is a system we have.
We are now it's in production since nearly one year not yet open because we're currently loading it and it is linked to the next generation of our unique system.
So it will go in production with the opening of the New York system, which is planned normally for middle of the year.
This is supposed as at a colleague of.
Mine's had prepared for the Open Repository conference last year in Edinburgh.
Just to pick up some of the of the details.
So first of all on the bottom left you see the definition site of the of the repository.
So we have what we call a common data model and ontology which is completed by named authority lists and that is arrows.
So the send Mantic model is build up of these components, Scientology controlled vocabularies.
Enter tesouros.
In the middle of the left there you see the loading.
As a loading is standardized.
Also we are using an international standard Mets metadata encoding and transmission schema for generating the packages which are sent.
User repository and you see already in the inside the metadata already in this stage is.
Provided an RDF.
That's the figure in below.
So for the moment we're Speaking of about 43 million files and about 13 terabytes of data.
In the repository itself you see two branches, so on the top we have the content repository which is built on an open source repository, Fedora Commons.
Where we store the content and also the metadata still serialized and external so that this is a real reference repository.
And below we have some meta data repository which is an RDF store.
On the right hand side you see as a distribution site, there's a big thing in the middle that is the ingestion note, which is not online.
And we are replicating the data and that use seeing on the right side to two distribution modes for notes for the moment, which are the access for our partners in the future?
And also we will create a sort distribution note for the sparkle and point.
Best on figures.
So we started the initial loading in May 2012.
At the 7th of March we were about 700 million triples in the store.
And you see quite different content.
Performance is the big majority PDF, but also considerable XML, HTML, index, HTML.
How can you access this data?
First of all, through a Restful API with content negotiation through the accept header.
That is an example of a screenshot to access the metadata of one of the first orgies from 52 of.
58 and that was loaded into the repository.
And on the other side, that is not yet the public sparkle endpoints at the sparkle endpoint of the seller admin interface, so that we are using in our daily work to access the RF store.
Second, which was not yet known when I did the last presentation that the CU data Portal.
So there was a decision in December 2011 where the Commission strengthened again his policy of reuse an in this decision.
They also clearly made a commitment to set up a new data portal.
So the Artikkel 5 of this decision.
Clearly stated that the Commission will set up an open data portal.
Meanwhile, the data portal is operated by the publication Office, so we are responsible for the operational follow up of the system.
And the development.
For the moment we had a better stage and you'll see also the URL on top, which is really ugly, but that is that is a small problem.
So the open data open slash data at the end that will definitely disappear.
That was an implementation error that will go with the next release.
Unfortunately I was not able to negotiate that.
We simply use data so that we have there some formal authorities who are responsible for the URL definition and their preferred this.
Open Data TLA is OK. Let's get some access.
Some details about the data portal which may be of interest here in this audience, though there's an RDF based interface.
Well, the upload of the metadata, those are partly itself.
It contains meta data.
The data sets are hosted by the data providers.
And the access is on the data provider side, but it's interesting.
Here is that the upload of the data is is done in RDF, that is an extract of the upload of data coming from our side.
So it is iaccessible through Sparkle Endpoint Officer of the Open Data portal.
And another important thing is that we see that more and more data providers are ready to provide data in RDF.

Eurofox that is already out there for quite a time and I think a lot of you noticed his arrows and that it's available also in skos RDF it is integrated as I said in the semantic model of the seller of the common repository, and it will also be provided in the future through the repositories or the.
Content will be stored in the repository and accessible through the repository.
Meta data registry.
So we have.
Set up a kind of metadata standardization initiative between the EU institutions, which is in the first phase dedicated to the exchange of legal information.
In this scope we have set up a metadata registry who receives.
The definitions of the concepts which have been validated and those who have been finally validated are also published on the Internet.
We have temporary site where you have C URL on top but also in the future.
It is foreseen that the data is stored in the common repository.
What is also not yet in place but which hopefully will come very soon is that we have in UI resolution until until the individual codes.
Of the controlled vocabulary lists.
What is interesting here in this context?
Just an example.
It's a bit small.
But here you see, for example for English.
You have all the translation in the official languages of EU.
So you can take from there there's a translation in the different languages, and yesterday we had a lot of her talking about quality and so on behind their insights.

Institutions there's a thing called Inter institutional style guides, so these kind of translation are discussed between all the translation services of the usual institutions, so we can have a certain reliability.
That is that there you have really so official recognized.
Relation by the different Member States.
Last not least, another subject which is the European legislation identifier.
Citizen Initiative, which is supported finally by the by the EU Council.
So that means by some Member States who has published in October last year.
Recommendation to the Member States to introduce European legislative identifier for their legal portals.
The idea behind is is really following the W 3C recommendation for RDF on XML.
So to include this information.
And the standardized way.
In the web pages so that the legal data can be linked, aligned and better exploited also by search engines.
One use case for us is to link the transposition of EU law to national legislation that can be very elegantly be done by by using these kind of.
Identification, passion techniques.
I have put the link in there for those who are interested to to read the text.
In the Official Journal.
OK.
Finished a bit before time.
Thank you very much for your attention.
Thank you.
